docs.lead_paragraph: Injections of steroids near the spine have been linked to other rare but devastating complications, including nerve damage, paralysis and strokes.

headline.seo: Spinal Steroid Injections Have History of Trouble
headline.main: Before a Wave of Meningitis, Shots Were Tied to Risks
headline.print_headline: Seeking Injections for Pain Relief, and Finding Themselves in Pain for Life

docs.abstract: Outbreak of fungal meningitis that has killed 14 people and sickened 156 more has focused attention on risk of infection from steroid spinal injections, which have long been linked to other rare but devastating complications; use of such injections has mushroomed even as clinical trials have found only modest evidence that they help.
docs.snippet: Injections of steroids near the spine have been linked to other rare but devastating complications, including nerve damage, paralysis and strokes.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a small, preliminary study, an experimental vaccine provoked a strong immune response against precancerous cells in women treated for early signs of cervical cancer.

headline.print_headline: Therapeutic Vaccine Shows Potential in Fighting Cervical Cancer

docs.lead_paragraph: A new wave of imaging technologies, driven by the falling cost of computing, is transforming the way doctors can examine patients.

headline.seo: Labs Seek New Ways to Look Inside the Body
headline.main: Laboratories Seek New Ways to Take a Look Inside
headline.print_headline: Laboratories Seek New Ways to Take a Look Inside

docs.abstract: Wave of new imaging technologies, driven by the falling cost of computing, is transforming the way doctors can examine patients.
docs.snippet: A new wave of imaging technologies, driven by the falling cost of computing, is transforming the way doctors can examine patients.

docs.lead_paragraph: Lesser versions of the electronic medical record leave many doctors scrambling, as the transition from paper to computer is not always a smooth one.

headline.seo: Hypertension or Hammertoe? To the Computer, It’s Just ‘HT’ - The Digital Doctor
headline.main: Which ‘HT’ to Treat: Hypertension or Hammertoe?
headline.print_headline: Which ‘HT’ to Treat: Hypertension or Hammertoe?

docs.abstract: Dr Abigail Zuger essay contends that while electronic medical records could one day be extremely effective, their current incarnation leads to diagnostic confusion and frustration.
docs.snippet: Lesser versions of the electronic medical record leave many doctors scrambling, as the transition from paper to computer is not always a smooth one.

docs.lead_paragraph: Electronic record systems can make health care more efficient and less expensive, but their potential for mistakes and confusion can be frustrating, costly and even dangerous.

headline.seo: The Ups and Downs of Electronic Medical Records - The Digital Doctor
headline.main: The Ups and Downs of Electronic Medical Records
headline.print_headline: The Ups and Downs of Electronic Medical Records

docs.abstract: Electronic medical record systems can make health care more efficient, cost effective and accessible, but their potential for mistakes and technological glitches can be costly and even dangerous; shift has been strongly promoted by the Obama administration.
docs.snippet: Electronic record systems can make health care more efficient and less expensive, but their potential for mistakes and confusion can be frustrating, costly and even dangerous.

docs.lead_paragraph: More hospitals and medical practices are adopting videoconferencing to treat patients, as Nantucket’s hospital has, finding that in many cases tele-treating can stand in for an office visit.

headline.seo: Nantucket Hospital Uses Telemedicine as Bridge - The Digital Doctor
headline.main: With Telemedicine as Bridge, No Hospital Is an Island
headline.print_headline: With Telemedicine as Bridge, No Hospital Is an Island

docs.abstract: Some hospitals and medical practices are adopting videoconferencing technology as an affordable and effective way for doctors to examine patients without seeing them in person; method is especially useful in remote locations or in medical specialties that face a shortage of physicians.
docs.snippet: More hospitals and medical practices are adopting videoconferencing to treat patients, as Nantucket’s hospital has, finding that in many cases tele-treating can stand in for an office visit.

docs.lead_paragraph: Medical care has improved greatly in the last century, but even with technological advances it remains far from perfect.

headline.seo: A Century of Progress Comes With Complications - The Digital Doctor
headline.main: Strides in Medicine, and Their Price
headline.print_headline: Strides in Medicine, and Their Price

docs.abstract: Dr Lawrence K Altman essay notes that technological advances have allowed medicine to progress more in the last century than in all of previous history; warns that over-reliance on technology, especially on testing and imaging, can lead to abuse by doctors who do not sufficiently rely on their own observational powers.
docs.snippet: Medical care has improved greatly in the last century, but even with technological advances it remains far from perfect.
